positive.review: The game is just incredible, No upgrades required, all people have the same cars so all depends on the player. It is not pay to win as well unlike other games. The game is extremely optimized and runs great even on weak hardware. For these reasons i am going to give it a 10/10.

Ubisoft is full of shit. Yearly subscription for full features. However, game nostalgic and I still like it. Wish it wasn't presented as a service, would even prefer a battlepass or once off purchase fee. It is still good at its root and there's enough in the free game to recommend. Even if you don't like it... its free. Launching Ubisoft connect to work is annoying as hell. Unnecessary and clanky.

The creativity that comes from community made tracks, clubs, and events makes this one of the most re-playable games I've played.  In the 650+ hours I've put into this game over the last five years, I have seen incredible tracks, and achieved great times that I hold immense pride in.  This is a game that rewards the dedication to improving your game, and putting in the practice. 

Play more grounded and serious tracks, or find one with boosters, loops, and jumps.  If you like racing games for the speed, this game is for you.  If you like racing games for the hunt of perfect lines and mastering technical turns, this game is for you.  If you like racing  games to pull of the cleanest drifts, this game is for you.  If you ever wanted to play a platforming game, but have your character be a car, that's weird but this game is still for you. 

This game stands apart from other racing games with its predictable and deterministic physics allowing your complete mastery of the car with the results of your time being in your complete control.  Another great way that this game stands apart from other racing games is its various driving surfaces.  Some surfaces offer incredible turning radius, and nearly infinite grip, and some others have you slipping and sliding around almost like you are driving on ice! (because you are.  There are tracks made of ice.) 
The track creator allows nearly infinite unique experiences that I can't get enough of.  
10/10 would recomend.

There's not much to say.  Watch some Wirtual on YouTube, if the game seems appealing to you, then it's definitely worth giving a try especially because it's free.  It's a pretty unique type of game so there's not really something to compare it to.

The free version gives you enough of a taste of the game that you can easily decide if it's interesting to you or not, and the paid version is actually very cheap, and when you buy it you unlock all current and past content, and get to keep all that content even if you don't continue your yearly subscription, so even though it's technically a subscription, you can easily look at it as a one time purchase for a large amount of content.

Awesome fun racer especially with friends, Free version is OK, but the subscription (works out at around 35pence per week)... gives access to a world of fun and customisation. 
I wish I'd found this game sooner! 
Simple to play, tough to master, very much a "just one more try...just one...last try... this one... ok this is definitely my last try..." 
Every Red time make you want more, every blue time is a dopamine hit.. even 0.001 seconds faster is ridiculously rewarding!
Try the free one if nothing else.. :)

The top reviews are complaining that the game is actually not free to play. And that's true. What you're getting for free is more like a free trial version. The full game is available on subscription which is $20 per year.

And I believe that the game is well worth the money! The gameplay is fun (at least if you're into arcade racing) and addictive. The controls are easy to grasp but hard to master and if you want you can literally spend hours improving your best time on a single track. The authors have done a good job to make all setups equally competitive so you can get good results with either a controller or a keyboard. There's a lot of content and new updates are being pushed regularly.

Overall I recommend to try the free version and then switch to the paid version if you're feeling like it. The subscription is 10x cheaper than Netflix and IMO 10x the fun.

Trackmania is a free-to-play racing game where everyone drives the same car, on the same track, with the same physics… and you still manage to be 3 seconds slower than some guy named “xX_TurnCut_666_Xx.”

It’s not about racing *others* in real time.
It’s about:

* Racing **ghosts**
* Racing **the clock**
* And mostly racing **your own bad muscle memory**

---

### Pros:

* Tracks are 10–60 seconds long, which is perfect because that’s exactly how long your focus lasts before you slam into a checkpoint.
* One button to reset to last checkpoint, one to fully restart, both used more than the accelerator.
* Editor lets the community create absolute war crimes of track design:

  * Ice
  * Dirt
  * Reactor boosts
  * “I swear this is drivable” wall-rides
* You will watch a world-record replay and genuinely question if you’re playing the same game.

---

### Cons:

* Bronze medal: “Nice try :)”
  Gold medal: “Okay, that hurt.”
  Author medal: “We know you’re not getting this, but here’s something to cry about.”
* Your friends list becomes a leaderboard of people you love but must destroy.
* No matter how clean your run feels, you *will* watch the replay and see three spots where you drove like a drunk shopping cart.
* One slightly bad turn? Restart. Miss a jump by 2 pixels? Restart. Breathed wrong at the start line? Restart.

---

### Peak Trackmania Moments:

* Nailing a drift perfectly, feeling like a driving god, then immediately choking the final jump.
* Saying “last run” and then doing 24 “last runs” because none of them felt spiritually correct.
* Beating your friend’s time by 0.003 seconds and treating it like winning a world championship.
* Spectating top players and realizing they brake in places you didn’t even know had physics.

---

10/10
It’s not really a racing game, it’s a precision platformer disguised as one car and a midlife crisis.
Would bonk the same corner 86 times, finally get a PB by 0.01, and scream like I won the F1 title again.

Good but you can't actually buy the game, just a yearly subscription. Makes it hard to recommend.

-No Steam achievements or basic Steam elements expected of a Triple-A developer that had an infinite amount of time to prepare for the game's arrival to Steam

-Game isn't actually free to play, its free to download. You're forced to purchase a recurring subscription service to access any actual content outside of a few default maps in singleplayer and the tutorial

-Subscription service is the only way to access all customization elements

-Only three player party sizes. Why tf? This game has SIXTY player lobbies, a three player party cap is insane

-Subscription service is the only way to access, create, or even view clubs

-Tutorial is garbage. You get a tiny track that exemplifies a specific mechanic within the game to practice on for each level and a personal best goal to achieve in regards to completion time. That's it. They don't teach or explain anything, not one word. Really odd decision

-The tutorial, and menus, are littered with gigantic glowing adds pushing you to buy their subscription service. It feels and looks like a mobile game in that regard and reeks of desperation

-Ubisoft only finally put this on Steam due to their recent financial troubles, pathetically crawling back to the hundreds of thousands of customers you've ignored, hated, treated like trash, and mocked won't go so smoothly

In conclusion, the driving in this game actually feels really good and it looks super nice visually. The amount of content available here is insane, thousands upon thousands of maps all different and unique with fantastic skin and map editor systems to top it all off and a solid club/social experience as well. However, all of these things are locked away behind an awful and manipulative paywall that's constantly shoved in your face but only after you've installed the game, having believed the false advertising and blatant lies that claim this game is free when it is no way whatsoever anything of the sort and would constantly charge you year after year just to maintain access to content you should have only needed to pay for a single time. Its absurd, disingenuous, and manipulative at best. In short? Its a damn shame Ubisoft still sucks this bad.

Trackmania have always been fun games, this one included.
Picked this one up recently because I was craving for some Trackmania and wanted to try it out. Had fun for a little bit, but very quickly the monetization system started to become annoying. Menus are a mess for new players, everything you click on it is locked behind the premium pass so you're constantly being reminded you need to pay. Basically you only have access to 10 season races, the weekly races, you're allowed to only join only one online server, and have access to ranked mode.

Ranked mode is fine for the first few ranks, but very quickly you start racing on maps that are unavailable to you to practice, so it becomes frustrating to you AND your teammates (because ranked is only 2v2) when you have to learn the maps while playing ranked.

I was thinking of getting the premium pass, but I'm not invested in Trackmania enough to buy a subscription to the game. I would've bought it if it weren't a one year pass only, because I was not counting on playing it non stop for a year and don't want to have to pay again in 5 years when I'll be craving some TM again.

I guess I'll just go back to Nations, it's simpler and less obnoxious game for casual players like me. Just pick and play, no subscription and locked content.

WTF.. Ubi !! You had ONE JOB and it was easy !

Original Todo List:
-Keep Original Biomes
-Develop a new Driving/Physics system 
-Create New Biomes (Could had been DLCS at worst)
-Add an Invite/party system compatible whit Steam.
-Ease Player Curated Content search whit an easier menu Search methods for a personalized playlists.
THATS IT !

What We Got:
-Slightly changed Driving/Physics system 
-Limited everyone to become a freemium user and only be able to run basic Stadium stuff.
-Added a Subscription model For the Original Old Biomes from the last 3 decade of trackmania.
-Added Player PARTY CAPS !? (This Game franchise used to run up to 100 players lobbies, WHAT THE ACTUAL F*#$&)
-No New Biomes.
-Made the Subscription service the only way to be able access user generated content
(FYI, originally. it was an utile p2p server browser model that already didn't needed any maintenance or costs to run...)

This the a prime example of UBI Hitting the deck real bad whit some Highway robbery for basically nothing new added..

imagine if EA would had did exactly that: Rebooted a new yearly NHL/FIFA Game and just kept one basic part of the game active freely and to only way to get the normal stuff now is trough a subscription whitout any additional real benefits...

This is how f*cked this is. Abusive DLC's arn't fun... but Abusive Subscription models is even worst.
Im not paying for this C*ap and nor im buyng ever again a single ubisoft game as long as they keep actively degrading and killing our beloved games franchises whit this crap.
This isn't gaming. This is a CEO corporate greed hellscape.

SUMMARY:
Don't waste your time or money whit this one, if you want a recent TrackMania experience, go play TrackMania2 from 2011, or if you really want to play it like it was meant to be played, go play TrackMania:United Forever Instead, its more respectfull to the actual Source material and offers more in terms of user generated content and freedom of play.

Final Score:
0/10
